data.title: Test TypeScript and JavaScript grammar updates
data.body:
**Issue:** 
**Assignees:**
- [ ] @jrieken 

**Details:**
The TypeScript/JavaScript grammars have been updated. They include multiple fixes, in particular:
- https://github.com/Microsoft/TypeScript-TmLanguage/issues/37 
- https://github.com/Microsoft/TypeScript-TmLanguage/issues/96
- check out multiple TS and JS files and have a look at type references and keywords.
- test all our 4 default themes

As this update also required changes to our default themes, we also need to test the default themes with other languages:
- [x] Bat @weinand 
- [x] Clojure @weinand 
  Known change: The light blue for definitions is gone. This was an accidental match.
- [x] Coffeescript @weinand 
- [x] C  / C++ @weinand 
- [x] C#
- [x] CSS @isidorn
- [x] Docker @isidorn
- [x] F# @isidorn
- [x] Go @isidorn
- [x] Groovy @bpasero 
- [x] Handlebars @bpasero 
- [x] HTML @bpasero 
- [x] Ini @bpasero 
- [x] Jade @isidorn 
- [x] Java @isidorn 
- [x] Javascript
- [x] JSON @isidorn 
- [x] Less @isidorn 
- [x] Lua @isidorn
- [ ] Make @alexandrudima 
- [x] Markdown
- [ ] Objective-c @alexandrudima 
- [ ] Perl @alexandrudima 
- [ ] Php @alexandrudima 
  The PHP meta tag now has the same color as other html tags
- [x] Powershell @isidorn 
- [x] Python @isidorn
- [x] R @isidorn
- [x] Razor @isidorn 
- [x] Ruby @bgashler1 classes are no longer colored when used (still colored when defined).  Seems to follow TypeScript's style.
- [x] Rust @bgashler1 
- [x] Sass @bgashler1 
- [x] Shaderlab @bgashler1 classes are no longer colored when defined. What used to be their color is now used for types.  Both of these differences seem odd (I don't use Shaderlab currently, though).
- [x] Shellscript @SofianHn 
- [x] Swift @SofianHn 
- [x] Tsql @SofianHn 
- [x] Typescript
- [x] Vb @SofianHn 
- [x] Xml/Xls @gregvanl
  The xml meta tag now has the same color as other xml tags on Dark+ and Light+. I think that's a good thing. It had been purple.
- [x] Yaml @gregvanl Attribute value blue is brighter on Light and Light+ themes.  Easier to read.

data.title: JavaScript syntax highlighting fails with ternary operator
data.body:
Hi!

Running Visual Studio Code v0.10.10, the following JavaScript lines are incorrectly highlighted:

``` js
let a = true ? true : true; // the last "true" should be colored
let a = true ? true : `this is ${incorrectly} highlighted`;
this should not be in yellow.
```

Here's what it looks like:

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/446986/13723459/738bcb36-e866-11e5-9742-cad114fa71e4.png)

data.title: Test HTML formatter options
Pressing Enter after Copyright maintains space:
data.body:
Press Enter after this text:

```
/*---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 *  Copyright (c) Microsoft Corporation. All rights reserved.
 *  Licensed under the MIT License. See License.txt in the project root for license information.
 *--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------*/
```

data.title: Char M and N are not displaying properly in intellisense with default theme and screen resolution 1280X800.
data.body:
OS: windows10
Screen Resolution:1280x800
Steps: 
1. Launch app.
2. Open one .cs file and type some text, starts with either M or N.
2. Verify intellisense window.

Actual: Char N and M is not displaying properly and hard to identify. It is displaying like solid square.
Expected: Default settings should support 1280x800 resolution.

data.title: [C++] syntax highlighting is not correct
data.body:
When I use vscode to browse the `db_bench.cc` in the source code of rocksdb, I found the syntax highlighting of C++ is incorrect. Illustrated below:
screenshot of syntax highlighting in vscode,
![vscode-cpp](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/2003731/13722206/6afe3726-e878-11e5-98d5-c5413a0eea9e.png)
whereas, the same content displayed in atom
![atom-cpp](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/2003731/13722208/82f1d590-e878-11e5-875d-63c96e6be337.png)

The colors used in atom editor is much richer, and it will not misinterpret keywords in strings such as `if` or `for`.
Environment:
ArchLinux 4.4.5 64bit
vscode 0.10.10
atom 1.5.3

data.title: [Javascript]Wrong Syntax Highlighter
data.body:
When the name of a variable begins with "var",VSC will make "var" as a kind of color and make the end of its name as a different kind of color.
However,if the name of a variable is "_var_",it will make its name as a kind color.
![-1](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/8530043/13721271/95c81ab6-e85b-11e5-9c10-f021ec277584.png)
- VERSION:0.10.10
- THEME:Light+
- NODEJS(My Project):v4.2.3(I used ES6)
- PLATFORM:Windows 10

data.title: VS Code provides odd hover expression to debug adapters if the expression has '.'s

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
This may well be by design, but if so I would suggest updating the documentation: https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/blob/master/src/vs/workbench/parts/debug/common/debugProtocol.d.ts#L475

When hoving over an identifier that doesn't start with a '.', the debug adapter just receives the identifier. This makes sense.
When hoving over an identifier that does start with a '.' the debug adapter seems to receive the full line of text.

I don't have a problem with making it the debug adapter's responsibility to find the start of the expression. But if I am reading [this code](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/blob/master/src/vs/workbench/parts/debug/browser/debugHover.ts#L97) code correctly, the UI seems to special case '.'. So I think we should either have the UI provide the debug adapter what it thinks is the right text (joining the dots together) or we should more fully move this responsibility to the debug adapter to handle more things (ex: '->' in C++).

data.title: Format Code broken with JavaScript after upgrade to vscode 0.10.10
data.body: I'm maintaining [vscode-standard-format](https://github.com/chenxsan/vscode-standard-format/blob/master/src/extension.ts#L37) extension, after upgrade to the latest Code v0.10.10, `Format Code` does not work when I try to format JavaScript code. When debugging, I found the [`format`](https://github.com/chenxsan/vscode-standard-format/blob/master/src/extension.ts#L8) function registered with `vscode.languages.registerDocumentFormattingEditProvider` was never called. I checked some other format extensions like https://github.com/kasik96/VSCode-PHP-Format/blob/master/extension.js#L67, it works in php language. ## screenshot

data.title: Problem passing args to PowerShell program in launch.json
data.body:
I'm trying to use Code on Windows to develop a PowerShell script. I encountered some difficulties when I tried to cut and paste a Windows path into the "args" parameter in my launch.json file.
1. I had to change "\" to "\\" to avoid a syntax error. That's inconvenient and ugly.
2. I haven't found a way to pass a space (blank) character embedded within a single argument.
3. The (x86) in the path causes PowerShell to give an error: x86 : The term 'x86' is not recognized as the name of a cmdlet, function, script file, or operable program.

So if my launch.json file contains:

```
        "type": "PowerShell x86",
        "request": "launch",
        "program": "${workspaceRoot}\\Compare.ps1",
        "args": ["C:\\Program Files (x86)", "arg1a arg1b"]
```

And the program is
`Write-Output "args:", $args`
Then when I run it, I get

```
x86 : The term 'x86' is not recognized as the name of a cmdlet, function, script file, or operable program. Check the 
spelling of the name, or if a path was included, verify that the path is correct and try again.
At line:1 char:48
+ c:\Src\Tools\BnA\Compare.ps1 C:\Program Files (x86) arg1a arg1b
+                                                ~~~
```

On the other hand, if I call my program from a PowerShell window, it parses the command line with two arguments just as I want:

```
PS C:\Src\Tools\BnA> Compare.ps1 "C:\Program Files (x86)" "arg1a arg1b"
args:
C:\Program Files (x86)
arg1a arg1b
PS C:\Src\Tools\BnA>
```

I think there are some bugs here, but maybe also a limitation in the allowed json file syntax. Right now single quotes aren't allowed in the json file for quoting strings. Would it be possible to have single quotes be a "stronger" type of quote mark that avoid any sort of interpretation, string substitution, etc. as much as possible, so file paths and other sorts of strings with funny characters can be passed in to the target program without a struggle?

data.title: [themes] Add styles to git commit changed, deleted, inserted
data.body:
Fixes #3991

@aeschli @bpasero 

The yellow/orange is .warn, red is .error, green is .comment but slightly lightened. I ended up going with `markup` instead of `git-commit` as that's what other themes seemed to be using.

data.title: workbench.files.action.closeFile closes all split editors, not just the active file

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
This is likely happening due to the recent change that makes closeFile close editors so it can close things like the default keybindings. When the command is run on a split editor it should only close the active editor.

cc @bpasero

data.title: Documentation suggestions
data.body:
Something that seems to be missing (and I would have found helpful as I was setting up and learning how to use Code) is an overview of the setup steps needed to create a usable code development environment. The documentation is very clear about how to add a debugger, but I had several questions about how to get other things set up. As an example of what I would like to see, this could be added to the Next Steps section near the end of docs/editor/setup. (I'd recommend moving the Additional Tools section after Next Steps section):
### Next Steps
- Read The Basics - Basic orientation around VS Code
- Add a debugger for your programing language (link to Debugger page)
- Customize the launch.json and tasks.json files for your development environment and workflow. See (here) for essential information about the syntax and available parameters that can be used in these files. **<-- This documentation is badly needed by those of us who aren't familiar with JSON**.
  - Customize launch.json to launch your application and supply command line arguments. (link)
  - Customize launch.json and tasks.json with a preLaunchTask that can build your application before running it. (link)
  - Customize tasks.json with a problem matcher to allow stepping through compiler errors and quickly navigating to the error locations in your source code. (link)
  - Customize for source control (link)
- Add an IntelliSense extension to provide "code understanding," highlight syntax errors in your code, help you find definitions of code objects (variables, functions, types...), etc. (link)
- Read Editing Evolved which introduces the features of IntelliSense.

(Put the Additional Tools section here.)

data.title: What is the correct behavior of running Code 0.10.10 from the command line?
data.body:
As requested by @bpasero in #4006, I'm opening an issue on this.

Using 0.10.10, when I run Code from the command line without any options specified, it always reuses the existing window. To get a new window, I have to specify the `-n` option.

Based on the `--help` output, this seems to be the expected behavior, but @bpasero seemed to think that it was unusual.

I have tested this on two different Windows machines and a Mac, and the behavior is the same in all cases.

I don't have any custom user settings on any of the installations, so I don't think anything is interfering there.

As far as repro steps go it's pretty simple:
1. Make sure Code isn't running
2. Open a Command Prompt / PowerShell window / bash terminal
3. Type `code` at the prompt
4. Repeat this several times and see that the focus goes to the existing window and no new windows are opened.
5. Type `code -n` at the prompt and a new window will open.

Is this the expected behavior for 0.10.10, or is something wrong?

data.title: Code instances lay around alive after delegating to already running instance
data.body:
OS: Windows 10
Build: new 0.10.12-alpha
Steps:
1. Install any old VS code build.
2. Launch app to verify installation is done properly.
3. Now close all the open instances and other program (cmd prompt) which has reference of VS code.
4, Now install latest alpha build from : *_https://vscode-builds.azurewebsites.net/alpha *_
5. Follow the install Wizard.
6. Proceed with installation by closing all the active program which are causing problem in installation (Look at the attached img :InstallWizard.jpg).
6. The installation wizard ask for replacing files and folder of the old build under : "C:\Program Files (x86)\Microsoft VS Code Alpha".
7. Click on next to proceed with installation.
8. If installation wizard unable to override files or not able to close all the references then it is giving options like: Abort, Retry or Ignore.
9. Select ignore option and proceed with installation 
10. If you get the same pop-up again then select "Abort" to rollback changes.
11. Once rollback is done try to launch previously installed app (directly from installed location or from command prompt).

Note: Verify VS code installed directory under : C:\Program Files (x86)\Microsoft VS Code Alpha.

Actual: 
1. When trying to launch app from command prompt (>Code-alpha ) I could see that the two instances of the app has been created in the windows task manager but app UI is not launching.
2. Looks like after closing all the active window some instances are left orphan in the system which is causing the issue to upgrade build.
3. I tried closing all the orphan instances manually from task manager and then only upgrade work properly.

Expected:
1. User should be able to launch an app when new installation is rolled back successfully.
2. I am not certain but each time two instances of the app is showing up in the windows task manager whenever I am launching app. Is this expected?
![installappandinstancesintaskmanager](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/17735796/13718006/aa9f5196-e79a-11e5-8336-0c985e71a588.jpg)
![installwizard](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/17735796/13718005/aa9ac112-e79a-11e5-8563-1464682d0b7a.png)

data.title: For-loop in JavaScript is colored turquoise/blue
data.body:
Here's an example:

![capture](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/791485/13717982/e8178412-e7e5-11e5-8b49-86b6774fb5c2.PNG)

Here's the code:
http://pastebin.com/gwSzquA0

The cause lies in the for loop declaration. It happens for `i<` , but not for `i <`, so the parser does something wrong there. Note the extra space.

data.title: F5 doesn't start program at all
[Node.js] Debugging Node.js stops responding after a number of step-over requests
data.body:
OS: Windows 10
Build#: 0.10.12-alpha
Node: 4.1.1

Node.js seems to stop responding after a certain number of step-over requests.

Steps:
1. Open provided Node.js project folder.
2. Set breakpoint in app.js at line 13. `var msg = "hello world";`
3. Start debugging
4. Step-over or press F10 about 40 times.
5. Node.js stops responding after reaching line 114 of timers.js
"Error: Node.js did not respond to request 'continue' in a reasonable amount of time"

Expected:
Node.js continues to debug

Files:
[311ExpressApp.zip](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/files/170061/311ExpressApp.zip)

data.title: Support virtual folder/file entries in the file view which are managed by extensions

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
When making an extension for some package manager it would be nice if there was an API for managing custom folders in the file view in the sidebar.

For example nodejs tools for visual studio is also having a dependency view in the project explorer:
![https://i.imgur.com/bGMLm19.png](https://i.imgur.com/bGMLm19.png)

I basically want to replicate that in vscode but there are no APIs for adding entries into the file view. So having some API allowing to manage some custom node or an extra region would be nice

2. Type Theme, Enter
3. Hold Up or Down key

data.title: Debug console shows even if externalConsole is true in 0.10.10
data.body: In my `launch.json` of my node.js project, I have `"externalConsole": true` and so it correctly opens in a new command window.  But in 0.10.10 now the embedded debug console also opens, with nothing output to it.  The expected behavior is that it shouldn't be shown at all.

data.title: Changing the debugging configuration while debugging doesn't work

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
1. I star a debugging session with "Launch configuration 1".
2. While it's running I change the configuration to "Launch configuration 2".
3. I stop the debugging session.
4. I start the debugging session, and while the label says "Launch configuration 2" it's actually using the configuration from "Launch configuration 1"

data.title: [Debug] Hover tooltip stays after leaving the editor window

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
OS: Windows 10
Build#: 0.10.12-alpha
Node: 4.1.1

Steps:
1. Debugging JavaScript
2. Some var definitions in the first 2 lines
Ex. 
`var express = require('express');`
`var path = require('path');`
3. Hover over 'path' to bring up tooltip
4. Quickly move cursor to the debug actions menu at the top
5. Tooltip for 'express' will stay open on the editor window until you move the cursor back into the editor.

The same happens if you quickly hover, then move the mouse out of the editor window at the right speed, a tooltip will stay open.

![tooltipopen](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/12900364/13716262/e399b632-e78e-11e5-9a92-0879ff85eaf3.JPG)

Expected:
Tooltip disappears when leaving the editor window.

data.title: Create rpm package test plan
data.body:
#4214 **Issue:** #3595

**Assignees:**
- [x] Linux - CentOS @dbaeumer  (couldn't fully test. See my comments below)
- [x] Linux - Fedora @SofianHn (similar to @dbaeumer I am blocked). 

**Details:**

_Test the rpm package install and uninstall_
1. Setup VM/machine
2. Download .rpm package from https://vscode-builds.azurewebsites.net/alpha
3. Install by opening .rpm package though the GUI (double click the file)
4. Ensure it installed correctly:
   - Opening "Code" through the launcher works
   - Running `code-alpha` through the terminal launches code
5. Uninstall: `sudo yum remove visual-studio-code-alpha`
6. Ensure it uninstalled correctly:
   - `/usr/bin/code-alpha` should not exist
   - `/usr/share/code-alpha` should not exist
7. Install via command line: `sudo yum localinstall vscode-x86_64.rpm`
8. Repeat steps 4-6.
